title: Cheap money keeps driving property higher
text:
No wonder global capital is pouring into hard assets such as office towers in Australia’s big cities. Australian real estate investment trusts — an investment product pioneered here — have been a top performer, still delivering 4-5 per cent yields.

With risk-free 10-year government yields down to 1 per cent or so, there is still a fair bit of ‘‘margin compression’’ left to push commercial property prices even higher.

Sure, this includes ‘‘stupid money’’, says veteran money man Trevor Loewensohn. That only matters if short-term refinancing forces you to sell during a downturn, suggests Darren Steinberg, chief executive of Dexus, Australia’s biggest office landlord.

Mr Steinberg says he’s been offered 20-year debt at just 2.7 per cent — long enough and low enough to ride out any storm.

Even with the soft economy, underlying demand for office space remains solid. Ironically enough, that’s partly because of the mountain of compliance and risk work being forced on financial institutions following the royal commission. It’s also because of the expanding urban workforces of Google, Atlassian and other tech companies.

It will surely unwind when interest rates exit their lowest levels in history. But that’s probably not for the next couple of years at least. In the meantime, the Reserve Bank’s lower-for-longer guidance is even pushing housing prices back up.

Mr Frydenberg welcomes this because the ‘‘wealth effect’’ should encourage people to shop more. And prices could keep rising because the slump in housing construction is likely to lead to shortages in a year or two.

Risk-averse banks, emboldened regulators and suffocating development red tape will ensure that supply lags population-driven demand.

It’s not clear, however, how that plays out with a household sector already heavily in debt and constrained by modest wages growth. Sooner or later, even cheap money has to be repaid.
description: While much of the economy remains subpar, it's boom time for much of commercial property. It will surely unwind when interest rates exit their lowest levels in history. But that’s probably not for the next couple of years at least.
